The original application requested $750,000 to fund approximately 60% of the cost of permanent acquisition from Deming Creek Ranch (Ranch) of rights to 1601.7 acre-feet of water, or up to 13.35 cfs early-season and 6.675 cfs late-season flow, for transfer to an in-stream water right.  The instream rights will be held in trust by the State of Oregon and managed by the Oregon Water Resources Department (WRD).      The increased instream flows proposed in this project will benefit a 6.9 mile primary reach in Deming Creek and a 2.5 mile secondary reach in the South Fork of the Sprague River (SFS). The secondary reach in the SFS provides habitat for Lost River and short-nosed suckers.

The Salmon Drift Creek Watershed Council (SDCWC) works within the Salmon River basin, the Devilâ€™s Lake watershed, and two significant tributaries (Drift and Schooner Creeks) that enter the Siletz River estuary in the town of Lincoln City. SWCWC has conducted a water quality monitoring program for the last 14 years. Portions of the Devilâ€™s Lake system, Drift Creek, Schooner Creek and the Salmon River are on the 303(d) list for a variety of parameters (temperature, dissolved oxygen, bacteria, and pH). In this proposal the Council will use trained volunteers from communities throughout the basin and students from the Mapleton schools to monitor temperature, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, clarity, bacteria, salinity and tidal stage (estuary sites only), and weather conditions at sixteen sites. The long-term monitoring goals include characterizing water quality conditions for each fifth-field HUC in the basin, and using the data to target problem areas for restoration efforts. For the past eighteen years, the Lincoln SWCD (District) has employed two skilled aquatic habitat surveyors for a variety of tasks including conducting Aquatic Habitat Inventories (AQI) and spawning surveys of spring and fall chinook, coho and steelhead in the rivers and streams of the area. Project Name: Mill Cr. Siletz Watershed Effectiveness Monitoring
Project Summary: Mill Creek - Siletz is a 7th-field watershed that flows into the mainstem Siletz at RM 49 in the community of Logsden. ODFW operates a Life Cycle Monitoring station in Mill Creek and has been collecting data on abundance of adult salmonids and survival and downstream migration numbers of juvenile salmonids there since 1997. This current monitoring application would quantify the effects of a watershed-scale large wood placement, planned to be implemented summer of 2015, on fluvial geomorphic response, aquatic habitat, assemblage of benthic invertebrates, overwinter survival of juvenile coho, and overall coho smolt production for the watershed. The study is designed to inform future in-stream restoration priorities, large wood placement design, land use management, coastal coho recovery goals and objectives, and limiting factors analyses for coho salmon production. Partners in the project with the MidCoast Council and ODFW include Plum Creek Timber, DEQ, OSU, and the Confederated Tribes of the Siletz Indians. OWEB funds are budgeted for contracted services (48%); 2-person field crew for three aquatic habitat inventory (AQI) surveys and project support (30%); travel (2%); supplies (5%); 2 outreach workshops (2%); and administration (13%).

Project Name: Kilchis Estuary Preserve Restoration Project - Revegetation Phase - PE

Project Summary: The 67-acre Kilchis Estuary Preserve property is a recently acquired diked and drained dairy farm located on the north bank of the lower Kilchis River in the Tillamook Bay watershed. The Nature Conservancy (TNC) purchased the property in late 2010/early 2011, with the goals of restoring freshwater and tidal connections, providing off-channel rearing habitat for salmonids and restoring historic spruce swamp habitat. In this application TNC proposes to conduct site preparation activities (herbicide treatments) prior to planting, plant 164,750 native plants (9,750 trees, 37,000 shrubs, and 118,000 willow cuttings), and conduct a variety of plant release/establishment actions (herbicide treatments and mowing) over the following three years. Partners in the project include NWFW (Oregon Governorâ€™s Restoration Fund), and the Northwest Oregon Restoration Partnership. OWEB funds for the combined planting and plant establishment components are budgeted for salaries (9%), contracted services (63%), travel (2%), supplies/materials (13%), and administration (15%).

The project would clear invasive species, plant native trees and shrubs, and conduct plant establishment activities for three years along 4,500 linear feet of the mainstem Nehalem River and along 8,000 linear feet of Foley and East Foley Creeks. Approximately 4,560 trees, 1,300 shrubs, and 10,600 willow cuttings total would be planted on the combined properties. The trees and shrubs would be protected, where necessary, with caging, tree guards and weed mats. Project Name: Clatskanie River Fish Passage Improvement Phase II
Project Summary: Several years ago the Lower Columbia River Watershed Council (Council) identified six fish passage barrier culverts within the Clatskanie Riverâ€™s headwater reaches that impaired juvenile and adult salmonidsâ€™ ability to reach the high quality habitat upstream. To date the Council has replaced two of the six culverts (numbers 2 and 3 working upstream) with open bottom structures 1.5 times the active channel width. In this new application the Council seeks funding to address site #4, where two side-by-side 6ft diameter culverts, in an 18ft active-channel-width stream, present a total barrier to juveniles and a partial barrier to adults. The plan is to replace the two undersized pipes with a 27ft bottomless arch culvert, a solution that will restore full passage for salmonids to a mile of spawning and rearing habitat upstream. Project partners include Columbia County Road Department, USFWS, ODFW and the Columbia SWCD. OWEB funds are budgeted for salaries (6%), contracted services (23%), supplies (59%), and administration (12%).

Project Name: Lower Columbia Restoration and Outreach Project (Lower Columbia  Project)
Project Summary: The Lower Columbia River Estuary Partnership (LCREP) is requesting funds to continue their Watershed Stewardship Project in elementary schools in lower Columbia River communities from Scappoose to Warrenton, Oregon; a five-year old program that will provide watershed involvement opportunities to over 500 youth and adults, including 15 third - sixth grade classes, teachers and community members. The program includes classroom lessons, field experiences, and a service learning watershed enhancement project. Classroom lessons will address watershed issues; service learning opportunities will address watershed preservation and restoration; and on-river paddling experiences will provide the participants with a memorable experience that hopefully will build passion for their local water resources. OWEB funds are requested for staff salaries (95%), travel (2%), and field supplies (2%).

Project Name: Sucker Creek Channel and Floodplain Restoration - Phase 3
Project Summary: The project is located in Sucker Creek, a tributary to the Illinois River in Southwestern Oregon. A total of 42 key large wood pieces will be placed by an excavator to create a series of seven self-maintaining large wood complexes over a 1,500 foot reach of stream. The structures are designed to create pools, increase habitat complexity and increase channel roughness.

Project Name: Fielder and Wimer Dam Removal Project

Fielder Dam is located at river mile 3 and Wimer Dam is located at river mile 10. This project will solve the fish passage problems associated with these two dams by removing the outdated structures. Fielder dam will be removed first and then Wimer Dam will be removed.

Project Name: Upper Umpqua River Restoration Planning Technical Assistance
Project Summary: Seven tributaries to the Umpqua River near Elkton have been identified as high priority for restoration: Sawyer, Bultler, Heddin, Mehl, Waggoner, Fitzpatrick, and McGee Creeks. Project Name: Restoring Habitat Diversity to Mid-Valley Conservation Areas, Phase II
Project Summary: Proposed project includes two locations, Bald Hill Farm in Benton County and Willamette Bluffs in Polk County; both of which have conservation easements and are located in Conservation Opportunity Areas.  Project addresses habitat loss and fragmentation, species diversity, and invasive species by restoring 68 acres of farm land and pasture to prairie, 8 acres of farm land to woodland, and 39 acres of degraded prairie, savanna and oak woodland.  This will improve conditions for federally listed Kincaidâ€™s lupine, Willamette daisy, Nelsonâ€™s checkermallow, and Fenderâ€™s blue butterfly.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, materials and supplies, and grant administration.  Project partners include landowner, state wildlife grant, and Greenbelt Land Trust.

Project Name: Courtney Creek In-stream Habitat Enhancement & Culvert Replacement
Project Summary: Courtney Creek flows through agricultural lands of the Calapooia Watershed and is a Meyer Memorial Trust Willamette Model Watershed basin.  Historically, this stream supported spawning and rearing habitat for Pacific lamprey, Chinook salmon, and winter steelhead.  Courtney Creek has limited in-stream large wood to promote stream channel processes that form habitat for native cold water fish, such as cutthroat and rainbow trout and lamprey; and has culverts that are fish passage barriers.  Proposed project will strategically place wood structures at 16 locations to restore stream channel processes that reconnect floodplain habitat, develop pools, and sort gravel; and replace two culverts with bridges to allow fish to access 6 stream miles.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, county land use planning, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include landowner, USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust, and Calapooia Watershed Council.

Project Name: Morgan and Johnson Creeks Log Placement Project
Project Summary: Morgan and Johnson Creeks are tributaries of McDowell Creek in the South Santiam basin, and primarily consist of private timberland, agriculture and rural residence land uses.  McDowell Creek is one of the few tributaries downstream of Foster Dam, which is a fish migration barrier.  Fish species in McDowell Creek include ESA-listed winter steelhead, resident trout and other native species; and potentially spring Chinook salmon and Pacific lamprey.  As part of the Willamette Model Watershed program, riparian and in-stream restoration projects have been implemented and monitored in McDowell Creek since 2008, which provided baseline information about stream conditions.  The lower portion of the basin exceeds state recommended water temperatures, and in the upper portion temperatures hover around the water temperature standard; and there is a lack of large wood structure throughout the basin.  Proposed project will place 28 structures with 210 logs at key locations in Morgan and Johnson Creeks to restore stream processes and improve connection of off-channel and floodplain habitats, pool development and maintenance, and gravel sorting throughout these streams.  The project area will be monitored for biological and stream channel changes.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use form, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include USFWS, Meyer Memorial Trust and South Santiam Watershed Council.

Proposed project will establish or enhance native riparian forest along 1.7 river miles of the middle Luckiamute and Little Luckiamute Rivers in Polk County.  As a result of historic and recent land use practices, many stretches along one or both banks of the rivers have limited or no native riparian forest.  Degraded or absent riparian buffers are not well functioning and do not provide canopy cover, surface water filtration, habitat connectivity, or bank stabilization benefits to the rivers.  Noxious weeds are encroaching on existing vegetation and disrupting forest regeneration processes.  Water quality monitoring from 2011 to 2013 identified exceedances of various standards for turbidity, bacteria (E. coli) and nutrients on both rivers.  Establishing or enhancing 33.7 acres of riparian corridor along 1.7 miles of these rivers will expand the benefits to listed Upper Willamette steelhead, cutthroat trout, Pacific lamprey, and other native species.  OWEB funds will be used for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use page, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include DEQ, landowners, FSA, and Luckiamute Watershed Council.

Project Name: Expanding the Benefit-Luckiamute Riparian Revegetation - PE
Upper Crabtree Creek Watershed Fish Passage
Project Summary: Proposed project is located in upper Crabtree Creek in the South Santiam Watershed where land is managed primarily by Weyerhaeuser and BLM.  Crabtree Creek watershed supports ESA-listed winter steelhead and Chinook salmon, Pacific lamprey, coho salmon, and resident trout species.  Project will address fish passage barriers on Crabtree Creek and Rock Creek, a tributary of Crabtree Creek.  An undersized, perched culvert at river mile 0.22 on Rock Creek blocks upstream fish migration to ~3 miles of spawning and rearing habitat.  The 1996 flood created a barrier waterfall at river mile 31.6 on Crabtree Creek that blocks upstream fish passage to 3.1 miles of designated steelhead Critical Habitat.  Project will replace the Rock Creek culvert with a channel-spanning bridge and construct a side-channel on Crabtree Creek to allow fish passage around the falls during adult steelhead migratory period.  At least 6.1 miles of fish habitat will be opened with the combined project sites.  Effectiveness monitoring will include snorkeling spawning surveys and physical habitat surveys.  OWEB funds are requested for project management, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, land use approval, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include Weyerhaeuser, BLM, ODFW, and South Santiam Watershed Council.

The STEWARDS Youth Watershed Council program will target K-12 students in Sweet Home, Central Linn, Albany, and Lebanon.  Youth are engaged in civic and watershed enhancement activities as they learn about watershed ecology, watershed councils and how to create change in their communities through participation in democratic institutions.  The Youth Watershed Councils provide students with opportunities to learn watershed concepts, apply those concepts to identify and implement their own restoration projects, and train them for future watershed leadership.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, event refreshments, and grant administration.  Project partners include The Nature Conservancy, Gray Family Foundation, Calapooia Watershed Council, and South Santiam Watershed Council.

Bird Haven Tree Farm (BHTF) is a 217 acre parcel located along approximately 1 mile of the Lower North Santiam River, just upstream of the City of Stayton in Linn County.  BHTF is located in a high priority 15 river mile reach of the North Santiam River, near significant existing restoration and conservation efforts along the mainstem river.  Habitat types on BHTF include floodplain forest, side-channel habitat, historic oak savanna, and upland prairie.  Habitat condition is currently compromised due to significant disturbance, lack of management for several years and presence of invasive species.  Douglas fir plantations of varying age classes occupy much of the historic habitats.  Many resident and migratory fish species, including Threatened Upper Willamette River spring Chinook and winter steelhead, as well as Oregon chub and Pacific lamprey, utilize the North Santiam mainstem in this reach.  Quality off-channel habitat is a high priority restoration need in the North Santiam River documented in the draft Willamette/Lower Columbia ESA Salmon and Steelhead Recovery Plan and other planning documents.  Upland prairies still have the capacity to support grassland bird species, such as Oregon vesper sparrow and western meadowlark, while providing necessary pollinator networks.  Proposed project will improve fish access to nearly a mile of side-channel habitat, restore floodplain vegetation on 47 acres and restore upland prairie restoration on 40 acres.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, land use approval, grant administration, reporting, and plant establishment.  Project partners include landowners, ODFW, USFWS, CREP, and North Santiam Watershed Council.

Greenbelt Land Trust proposes to restore 144 acres of forest, oak woodlands and savannas at Bald Hill Farm located in Benton County and in a Conservation Opportunity Area.  Project addresses habitat loss and fragmentation, species and habitat diversity, invasive species, and conifer encroachment.  Habitat restoration will increase the extent of oak woodlands and savanna, improve habitat for 10 of the 14 Oregon Conservation Strategy bird species already utilizing the site, and prevent further loss of oak habitat.  Conservation easements on Bald Hill Farm provide protection in perpetuity for conservation purposes.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include NRCS and Greenbelt Land Trust.

Milton Creek watershed drains approximately 34 square miles of Columbia County before terminating into Scappoose Bay.  Historically, this watershed was one of the most productive salmonid watersheds of Scappoose Bay; however, splash damming practices in the early 1900â€™s significantly reduced the amount of large woody debris and instream logs resulting in degraded habitat.  Proposed project will install wood and restore habitat along 3.2 stream miles.  This stream section was recently identified in a limiting factors analysis as an anchor habitat for coho smolt production, and also contains steelhead and cutthroat.  Lack of large wood was cited as a major limiting factor, with only 0.5 key pieces found per 100 meters.  An OWEB-funded Technical Assistance project identified 15 reaches within this section for large wood placement, and completed plans for wood configuration, stream access and material source.  A DEQ 319 grant will support non-native vegetation control and planting 6,400 native plants on 8.5 acres to increase biodiversity, reduce solar exposure and provide future large wood recruitment.  This large wood project and riparian planting will be monitored for three years.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services, travel, supplies and materials, grant administration, monitoring, and reporting.

Project Name: McKenzie Watershed Education and Outreach Project
Project Summary: Proposed project targets middle- and high school students from three school districts, university students and private landowners within four priority watershed areas.  Outreach through inquiry-based, field-focused activities is integrated with active watershed restoration, monitoring and enhancement efforts, and development of future projects.  Student teams with focus areas in water quality, stream habitat assessment, project survey, and restoration will collect data, assess habitat conditions, monitor restoration projects, and restore native tree and shrub plant communities.  Program activities and data are used for outreach to private landowners to develop voluntary enhancement projects.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, travel, printing, and grant administration.  Project partners include Springfield Public Schools and McKenzie Watershed Council.

Project Name: Upper Sandy River Habitat Restoration Project
Project Summary: The Sandy River Basin Partners identified Salmon River and Still Creek as providing high quality anchor habitat for the basinâ€™s native fish, and have prioritized these sub-watersheds for basin-scale restoration.  Sandy River salmon and steelhead populations have declined over the last century due to degradation of habitat and other factors.  Project will increase side-channel/floodplain connectivity on Salmon River and Still Creek.  Restoration actions include: reactivation of flow to 5 side-channels, construction of 29 large wood habitat structures, restoration of connectivity to one alcove, boulder placement, and placement of large wood in side-channel habitat and stream margins.  Post-project monitoring will follow construction to establish as-built conditions.  Physical habitat surveys will be repeated in summer 2015 and after bankfull events.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, and reporting.  Project partners include USFS, BLM, City of Portland, NFWF, Pacific Power Blue Sky Fund, and The Freshwater Trust.

The Calapooia Watershed Council (CWC) and its partners, including Weyerhaeuser, US Forest Service, Oregon  Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW), private residents, and Environmental Protection Agency  Western Ecology Division, joined to form a technical advisory committee (TAC) to address monitoring and restoration needs for the Upper Calapooia.  While there has been research throughout the Calapooia related to water quality, flows and biophysical impacts of small dam removal, very little fisheries monitoring has taken place due to agency capacity limitations.  To inform future TAC discussions regarding headwaters restoration or future attempts by ODFW to jump-start the Chinook population through seeding, we must understand current production levels of steelhead and Chinook. With significant ODFW contribution, proposed project will perform 30-miles of spawning surveys for Chinook and steelhead as well as Pacific lamprey.  Also supported is a one-time upper Calapooia snorkel including side-channel habitats and spawning gravel survey.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, equipment, and grant administration.

Project Name: Lower Long Tom River Fish Passage and Floodplain Restoration Project
Project Summary: The goal of the project is to begin planning holistic restoration of the Long Tom River between Fern Ridge Dam and the Willamette River. This reach of the River was channelized by the US Army Corps of Engineers in the 1940â€™s to reduce flooding, cutting its length from 36.5 to 23.6 miles. Three low-head dams were also installed to control the channel grade, blocking upstream migrations of important fish like juvenile upper Willamette River spring Chinook and Pacific lamprey.  OWEB funds will be used to perform floodplain inundation mapping, hydraulic/hydrologic modeling, and develop a community needs and opportunities analysis and restoration plan.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, and grant administration.  Project partners include a private donor, USACE, McKenzie River Trust, community leaders, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

Proposed project includes three programs to engage students, teachers and volunteers in stewardship opportunities that promote individual and community responsibility for watershed health. Over 400 on-water volunteers will participate in the Down by the River Clean Up and Stash the Trash Campaign, 20-40 teachers will learn watershed-based curriculum, and 410 students will raise salmon in the classroom, toss carcasses into Clackamas tributaries, receive a watershed presentation, or engage in riparian restoration.  These activities promote active involvement in stewardship by providing hands-on learning opportunities through workshops, watershed presentations, salmon life cycle, riparian restoration, and river clean-up activities.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, supplies and materials, equipment, other costs, and grant administration.  Project partners include Clackamas County, Clackamas River Water Providers, Chrysalis Farm, ODFW, DEQ, and Clackamas River Basin Council.

Project Name: Coyote Creek South: Wet Prairie-Vernal Pool Restoration Phases 1 and 2
Project Summary: Proposed project is located on Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlifeâ€™s (ODFW) 309-acre Coyote Creek South property in the Long Tom Watershed among a complex of more than 8,500 acres of protected lands comprising the West Eugene Wetlands and Fern Ridge Wildlife Area.  Coyote Creek South hosts native riparian habitat; and intact and restorable oak savanna, ash swale, wet prairie, emergent wetland, and vernal pool habitat.  This area currently supports, or is capable of supporting, native plant species, invertebrates, and vertebrates partly or wholly dependent on native Willamette Valley habitats.  Proposed project will restore 116 acres in the northern portion of the property from agricultural wetlands to a mosaic of wet prairie and vernal pool habitat.  This restored habitat will support diverse native plant species, northern red-legged frogs and other native amphibians, and grassland birds, in particular federally threatened streaked horned larks.  Less than one percent of wet prairie habitat remains in the Willamette Valley, and habitat loss and fragmentation is the major limiting factor affecting prairie dependent wildlife species.  OWEB funds are requested for project management staff, contracted services for design and implementation, travel, supplies and materials, grant administration, reporting, and effectiveness monitoring.  Project partners include ODFW, USFWS, BLM, technical advisors, and Long Tom Watershed Council.

Project Name: Coyote Creek South: Wet Prairie-Vernal Pool Restoration Phases 1 and 2 - EM

Grantee: Friends of Buford Park & Mt Pisgah
Project Name: Meadowlark East Prairie & Oak Savanna Project
Project Summary: Project is located in southeast portion of Lane Countyâ€™s 2,363-acre Howard Buford Recreation Area near the confluence of Willametteâ€™s Coast and Middle Forks and adjacent to The Nature Conservancyâ€™s 1271- acre â€œWillamette Confluence Preserve.â€ù  Buford Park contains one of Oregonâ€™s largest expanses of publicly-owned â€œglobally endangeredâ€ù Willamette Valley upland prairie and oak savanna.  Decades of fire suppression have contributed to encroachment by Douglas fir.  In addition, invasive plant species have degraded native botanical diversity and wildlife habitat.  This project will restore and enhance prairie and savanna habitat across the 275-acre â€œMeadowlark Projectâ€ù on Buford Park.  Management actions will: 1) restore oak savanna on 55 acres by removing native conifer (including Douglas fir) and hardwoods; 2) restore prairie on 31.5 acres by removing encroaching native conifer and small exotic trees; 3) enhance oak woodland on 21.5 acres by thinning fir and some hardwoods; 4) suppress invasive herbaceous and shrub species; and 5) broadcast seed mix of grasses and forbs in areas of invasive control and tree removal to enhance habitat diversity and forage for wildlife.  These actions are expected to benefit 17 at-risk species known to occur in the Mt. Pisgah area that depend on these prairie, oak savanna and oak woodland habitats, including Western meadowlark and acorn woodpecker.  OWEB funds are requested for staff, contracted services, travel, materials and supplies, grant administration, outreach, and reporting.  Project partners include Lane County, BPA, USFWS, and Friends of Buford Park and Mt. Pisgah.

Project Name: Crooked River Watershed Sage Grouse Conservation
Project Summary: Funds will be used by the Crook Soil and Water Conservation District (SWCD) in partnership with Deschutes SWCD to develop site specific plans (SSPs) protecting sage grouse habitat on private range lands in Crook and Deschutes counties. These plans would then be enrolled into a multi-county Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances prior to a pending endangered listing of the sage grouse by United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to be determined by September, 15th, 2015. The SWCD will use existing relationships with landowners and new outreach activities in an effort to engage and enroll at least 30% (70 landowners) of landowners in sage grouse habitat in Crook in Deschutes counties in SSPs.  These plans include land management practices such as grazing management, riparian protection, rangeland restoration, weed management and others  intended to protect and restore important sage-steppe habitat which will be both critical to the long-term sustainability of sage grouse as well as other sage-steppe related species. Similar work has been done successfully in Harney County.

This project would establish a Youth Watershed Council among the Natural Resource Students of Culver High School.  Students would work both inside and outside the classroom, learning watershed science and restoration techniques, and conduction on-the-ground restoration activities in the McMeen Creek and Willow Creek drainages. This work would dovetail with ongoing and proposed restoration by the US Forest Service and Middle Deschutes Watershed Council (MDWC) in Jefferson County. MDWC and the school would partner with USFS personnel who have experience working with successful youth council models in the Willamette Valley to develop curriculum and projects associated with the youth watershed council.

Project Name: Willow Creek Upland and Riparian Enhancement
Project Summary: Willow Creek is a tributary of the Deschutes River that flows into Lake Simtustus above Pelton dam. Above Madras, Oregon, the creek flows through a narrow canyon on Crooked River National Grasslands (CRNG). Despite downstream dewatering, passage barriers, and water quality issues, above Madras, the riparian area is largely intact and the creek supports a population of native redband trout and other wildlife including nesting bald and golden eagles. However, there are areas of heavy juniper invasion into what used to be sage-steppe uplands. MDWC proposes 1,850 acres of juniper treatment in the uplands alongside Willow Creek.  This project is a continuation of non-OWEB funded work downstream in the canyon.  Juniper will be cut and burned, and where appropriate, left in the creek to encourage stream complexity and provide instream habitat. Partners in this project include USFS-CRNG and Jefferson County SWCD.

Cottonwood Creek is a tributary to Thompson Creek which flows into Goose Lake (currently dry) in Goose Lake Basin, Lake County. Goose Lake Basin is home to at least seven endemic fish species, most of which are Oregon State Sensitive Species, and all can be expected to use the lower reaches of Cottonwood Creek at some life stage. Land use practices including over grazing, diversions for irrigation (many unscreened), and extreme draught have all impacted riparian and aquatic habitat in the basin. This project will combine two irrigation diversions to one of the existing points of diversion. The upstream structure functioning as the combined point of diversion will be replaced with a pre-cast weir and fish ladder.  The lower structure will remain to prevent headcutting, but will be made passable for fish and other species through grade control structures below the diversion. The structure will include a flow measuring device and a pre-cast screen box for future fish screen installation. Stream bank and channel restoration will be included in the project. Partners in this project include the landowner and Ducks Unlimited.

Project Name: Goose Lake Basin Stream Reconnaissance Plan
Project Summary: Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council (LCUWC) will contract for a comprehensive stream reconnaissance plan to determine limiting factors and priority restoration projects on private stretches of twelve streams (180 miles) located in the Goose Lake Watershed, the largest basin in Lake County.  The USFW will conduct concurrent surveys on public lands. A similar survey was previously conducted by LCUWC on Thomas Creek, a major tributary to Goose Lake, and it has been used to successfully identify and plan restoration activities including improving fish passage, irrigation diversion replacement and screening, stream channel and riparian restoration, and grazing management along over 40 miles of Thomas Creek. Similar projects are expected as a result of this plan.

Project Name: Upper Thomas Creek Restoration Phase III
Project Summary: Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council (LCUWC) will address the remaining twelve priority projects outlined for Upper Thomas Creek, a major tributary to Goose Lake northwest of Lakeview, OR.  Thomas Creek is home to multiple endemic species including redband trout and federally listed Modoc suckers.  Proposed projects will occur on private and National Forest land and will address fish passage, instream habitat, channel instability, bank erosion, riparian vegetation and grazing management issues.  Previous work has been done on Thomas Creek by Lake County Umbrella Watershed Council and partners including the US Forest Service, Lakeview Soil and Water Conservation District and Ducks Unlimited.  After the proposed work is completed, all priority projects on Thomas Creek will have been completed, enhancing over 40 miles of river from the headwaters to the mouth at Goose Lake. OWEB has been a funding partner on many of these projects.

Project Name: Crook County Natural Resources CTE Outreach Program
Project Summary: This project is a continuation of a past OWEB grant (213-4028) for enhancement of a highly successful Career Technical Education â€“ Natural Resource Management Program of Study at Crooked River High School. Students are taught watershed and restoration science and engage directly in restoration activities. There are 54 field days included in this project. The Crooked River Watershed Council (CRWC) works directly with the school to provide hands-on examples of the type of restoration concepts that students are learning about. The work performed and information gathered by the students is actually being used as part of project implementation and monitoring. This project has been extremely successful, both in engendering community support, but also in attracting media and congressional attention to the project. Graduates of this program have successfully obtained summer natural resource work in competition with college level applicants. This continuation of the project is focused on broadening the program to include elementary-age kids.

This project would improve floodplain connectivity, riparian conditions, fish passage and instream habitat along three miles of Horse Heaven Creek and three-quarters of a mile of the Crooked River their confluence. This sub-watershed is about six miles above Prineville Reservoir in Crook County. The project area has been impacted by historical overgrazing and includes a large reservoir and four downstream diversions, all of which are at least seasonal barriers to fish passage. There are native redband trout actively using Horse Heaven creek for spawning. There has been active management by the landowner in conjunction with the Crooked River Watershed Council and other partners of juniper and historical grazing issues to help restore native species in upland habitats and restore watershed function on this 32,000 acre sub-watershed, of which, 18,600 is owned by a single landowner. Much of the area has been fenced for improved livestock management. Some of this work was funded through a previous OWEB grant and the landowner has also born significant costs related to restoration activates. This project would install fish screens and provide passage at two active diversions, remove two diversions which are passage barriers and are no longer used. Partners in this project include the landowner and USFWS Partners Program. [Previously proposed instream work has been removed to reflect a reduced budget].

Project Name: Warner Ranch Wetland Enhancement and Fish Passage Project
Project Summary: DUâ€™s project will replace an earthen push up dam at the mouth of Drewâ€™s Creek and Goose Lake with a concrete diversion including a fish ladder, providing passage at the only remaining fish barrier between Goose Lake and Drewâ€™s Reservoir benefiting endemic Goose Lake Basin fish species.  In this unique system, and although the lake is currently dry, in wet years, connection to the lake performs an important function for the reproduction and rearing of endemic fish such as redband trout. They migrate out to the lake, grow rapidly and then return to the stream to spawn. It has been suggested by ODFW biologist that this periodic event is important to the persistence of fish species in the basin.

Big Summit Prairies is a private parcel surrounded by the Ochoco National Forest north and east of Prineville. It is comprised of high-elevation ponderosa pine forest, shrub-steppe uplands, wet meadow, and riparian areas along the banks of the North Fork of the Crooked River and associated tributary streams which feed the meadow system.  There are native redband trout and associated riparian wildlife found in the area. It is also an important area for elk. There is federal land and Wild and Scenic River designation both upstream and downstream of the prairie.  There are legacy resource issues related to homesteading the area (i.e., ditching, diking), compounded by years of poor grazing management.  Current ownership of eastern half of the prairie, approximately 9,000 acres, are interested in assessing the current state of the property and conducting restoration activities to address irrigation efficiency, floodplain connectivity, fish passage and screening, and erosion issues, among others.  They recently paid for a Proper Functioning Condition Assessment of their ranch properties.   CRWC will use this information to work with the landowner and agency partners to develop a restoration action plan that will address irrigation and grazing management, forest management, fish passage, stream/riparian function, and aquatic habitat. It is anticipated that multiple restoration projects will flow from this assessment and plan.

Project Name: Evans Creek Restoration and Culvert Replacement at Hutson Drive
Project Summary: Hood River County intends to correct a longstanding passage barrier issue for Evans Creek, a tributary to the East Fork Hood River.  The creek is important in that clear (non-glacial) tributaries are rare in the Hood River Basin, and this is important spawning habitat for federally listed winter-run steelhead. There are currently a perched culvert at Houston Drive, and a buried culvert downstream that was part of an earlier failed restoration attempt. Fixing the perched culverts at Houston Dr. and removing the instream culvert and restoring the channel will open up an additional 1.3 miles of habitat for federally listed winter steelhead. There is additional habitat potential upstream with the completion of future culvert projects.

Project Name: Landscape Restoration of Upper Crooked River Basin
Project Summary: The Nature Conservancyâ€™s Juniper Hills Preserve lies in the Upper Crooked River Basin near Post, Oregon.   This project is part of a larger plan to restore 10,000 acres of sagebrush-steppe, dry pine, and forest-sagebrush and juniper woodlands on the preserve. Project components include pre-burn treatment and prescribed fire on 1,830 acres, juniper cutting on 1,030 acres, planting native seed with Precision Restoration techniques including new seed treatment (seed are encased in charcoal so they withstand initial herbicide treatment for noxious weeds) and targeted weed treatment. There is no grazing by domestic livestock on Juniper Hills. There are no funding partners involved in this project; however, they do have letters of support from Crooked River Watershed Council, Crook County Soil and Water Conservation District, and USDA- Forest Service Paulina Ranger District.

Project Name: Grande Ronde Basin Stream Flow Gauging Stations Operation - Water Years 2015 & 2016
Project Summary: The Grande Ronde Model Watershed (GRMW) is proposing to continue monitoring 12 streamflow gauges throughout Union and Wallowa Counties. The project continues the operation, maintenance, record production and review of the twelve gauges in the Grande Ronde basin.  The project intends to produce the highest quality data possible achieved through a production partnership between GRMW and OWRD.  OWRD will complete all work under contract with the GRMW.  In addition, five U.S. Forest Service (USFS) gauges characterize hydrographs for long-term monitoring of management activities on streamflow and currently provide essential data in that portion of the basin.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%). Cost-share partners include Bonneville Power Administration, GRMW and OWRD.

Overstreet Drain, one of five major drains to the Owyhee River, flows in at rivermile (RM) 6.  The OWEB-funded Newell pressurized pipeline services the Overstreet drain area and was fully installed in 2014.  The project proposes to install a pivot to irrigate 31 acres.  Corners will be irrigated with solid-set handlines on the remaining 8 acres.  Project components include:  installing 900 feet of cable con; 760 feet of 12-inch pipe to replace a small drainage ditch; 4,500 feet of 6-inch pipe along field borders; 6 removable steel bridges to cross Overstreet drain and a 609-foot pivot. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (6%), water-right transfer (3%), materials- pipe, electrical (79%), administration (9%) and monitoring (1%).  The landownerâ€™s cost-share is 200% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Located four miles south of Adrian, Owyhee Watershed Council (OWC) proposes to convert 63 acres to permanent sprinkler-pivot. Project components include installing: 1,920 feet of cable-con; 1,260 feet of 8-inch pipe mainline from the lateral to the pivot point; 2,510 feet of 4-inch pipe from the lateral to the northeast field; 20 riser assembles in the pivot corners for handlines and a 1,218-foot Valley pivot.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (10%), materials- pipe, bubblers, pumps (76%) and administration (10%). Price Seed farm has a 208% cost-share of the OWEB-requested amount.

Baker Valley SWCD is seeking funds to design a pipeline for 1.5 miles of MaHarry-Belvins Ditch (MBD) from the Wolf Creek reservoir to the P-2 connector inlet.  Baker Valley SWCD is seeking a professional engineer with expertise with hydrology, ditch practices and pipelines.  The 100% design will tie the existing P-2 pipeline to the Wolf Creek dam.  By drawing the exact amount of water needed, there will be less water withdrawn from Wolf Creek and more left for bull trout habitat in the reservoir.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted services (91%) and administration (9%). Powder Valley Water Control District and Baker Valley SWCD are the cost-share partners.

This project is located near Sumpter along the McEwen Valley ditch to provide off-stream water by developing a spring and conveying water into four troughs. Once the spring is developed and livestock water provided, the McEwen Valley ditch can be closed for the winter. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (1%), contracted services (50%), materials (36%) and administration (13%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner providing 57% cost-share and will provide the cistern and labor for the pond.

Project Name: Zumwalt Prairie and Imnaha Medusahead Rye
Project Summary: The Wallowa Canyonlands partnership (WCP) is a cooperative weed management area that protects and restores private and public canyon grasslands of the Snake, Imnaha and Lower Grande Ronde River watersheds from invasion and degradation by noxious weeds.  Project components include an aerial and ground inventory in high-risk areas to identify infestation and treatment areas; treat noxious weed infestations on 833 acres and restore degraded lands to productive plant communities after treatment.  Aerial inventory will be targeted towards Medusahead, yellow starthistle, Scotch thistle, plumeless thistle and rush skeletonweed. OWEB funds are requested for wages (13%), contracted services (48%), travel (<1%), materials (22%) and administration (13%). Cost-share partners include various landowners, BLM, Roberts Land & Cattle, TNC, Oregon Weed Board, Title II, McClaran Ranch and other landowners.

Project Name: Lostine River/Sheep Ridge Fish Passage Improvement
Project Summary: The Lostine River is a major tributary to the Wallowa River and habitat to ESA-listed spring Chinook salmon, steelhead and bull trout. A diversion structure affects spring Chinook salmon and steelhead.  Spring Chinook migrate to their spawning areas between July and mid-September. Summer steelhead migrate up the Lostine in late winter and spring. Proposed  components include installing 7 full-spanning, â€œVâ€ù-shaped, grade-control structures; 12 rock ribs between each grade-control structure; large-scale roughness boulders 36 to 48 inches buried 60% below the stream bed and streambed simulation material to aid sediment transport.  OWEB funds are requested for contracted service (91%) and administration (9%). BPA and Grande Ronde Model Watershed Program are providing 109% cost-share.

The High Desert Youth Camp has been held for the last four years at the Great North Basin Experimental Range.  The High Desert Youth Camp targets two specific audiences.  The first is high school students who have an interest in attending college to pursue careers in natural resources and wildlife management.  The second audience is college students already enrolled in a range or natural resource program. OWEB funds are requested for wages (32%), travel (14%), materials (27%), equipment (18%) and administration (9%). Cost-share is from EOARC, OSU, ARS, Harney County Watershed Council, TNC, TVCC and private donations and is 101% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Located near Harper, an 80-acre flood-irrigated field borders the Malheur River. To eliminate the runoff from the field, the applicant proposes to install a pivot that will transport water from an existing pond. Project components include installing a 25-hp pump; electrical power and panel box; 2,240 feet of 8-inch mainline from the pond to the pivot point and a 1,060-foot Zimmatic pivot to irrigate 80 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (4%), contracted services (3%), travel (1%), materials (83%), administration (6%) and monitoring (2%). The landowner is the cost-share partner.

The Cowboyâ€™s Big Circle project is located in the newly created â€œVale Bench Focus Areaâ€ù designated recently by ODA and Malheur SWCD. Project components include installing:  900 feet of 6-inch mainline from Lateral 227; 1,660 feet of cable-con wire; electrical panel; filter; 4 bridges to cross lower lateral and install pivot on pad. OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (5%), contracted services (4%), materials (80%), administration (8%) and post-implementation status reporting (2%). The project has 220% cost-share with the landowners and NRCS.

This project is located on Clover Creek in northwestern Malheur County.  Juniper removal is proposed on 2,000 acres (SGI); juniper removal and slash abatement on 160 acres of Clover Creek; plant 600 willow vertical bundles along 2,400 feet of streambank along Clover Creek; protect plantings with 240 juniper carcasses placed at the toe of the bank.  To enhance aspen, juniper will be removed along 2.8 miles of the riparian area (120 acres) and a machine and hand-piled juniper â€œfenceâ€ù will protect aspen regeneration in 6 priority areas on 15 total acres.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (6%), contracted services (82%), mileage (1%), administration (9%) and post-implementation monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners are Rupp ranches and NRCS and are 208% of the OWEB-request amount.

The Malheur Basin consists of approximately 5,000 square miles in southeastern Oregon mostly in Malheur and Harney Counties.  Approximately 70% of the basin is federally owned by primarily BLM. Malheur Watershed Council (MWC) and Malheur SWCD have been monitoring the Malheur River basin intensively for many years. The sampling design and monitoring programs are being refined continually. Project components include installing 8 field stations with pressure transducers to measure water level or â€œstageâ€ù hourly.  Streamflow measurements will be made according to USGS methodology every 4 to 6 weeks to define the stage streamflow relation used to compute continuous streamflow record.  Selected sites are based on focus-area monitoring in Willow Creek. Criteria for the selected sites include being in a priority area; contributing to water quality issues; securable site and nearby existing gauging station. OWEB funds are requested for wages (13%), contracted services (23%), travel (5%), equipment (50%) and administration (9%).  DEQ and BOR are providing significant cost-share.

Located six miles west of Juntura in northwestern Malheur County, the applicant will remove 1,000 acres of juniper using a chainsaw.  A masticator will be used on 250 acres on slopes less than 20% to reduce heavy slash concentration.  Juniper boles will be shredded by a rotary head mounted on a tracked vehicle.  In addition, 40 acres of isolated Medusahead patches will be sprayed with PlateauTM at a rate of 6 ounces per-acre.  After a full year, broadcast seed (15 lbs/acre) will be applied with a mixture of Siberian, tall, bluebunch and crested wheatgrass, Shermanâ€™s big bluegrass and sheep fescue.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/project management (6%), contracted services - juniper removal (78%), materials -seed (4%) and administration (9%).  The landowner is the cost-share partner of 47%.

Powder Basin Watershed council (PBWC) hopes to engage more community members and agency partners in the process of developing a basin-wide strategic plan that will govern the councilâ€™s efforts to address limiting factors over the next 10 years. PBWC also wishes to increase public awareness and participation in council activities. Project products include a quarterly print and electronic newsletter; four informal meetings in communities not currently represented by members; direct mailing to 10% of households; social media and website development. OWEB funds are requested for wages (81%), travel (<1%), other (16%), administration (1%) and equipment (<1%).  Meyer Memorial Trust will provide 33% cost-share.

PBWC is seeking technical assistance for 2.3 miles of the lower reaches of Clear Creek along these seven ownerships. The resulting restoration project will address in-stream habitat improvement, grazing and wildlife management concerns and provide a plan to address increasing channel complexity and riparian health. In addition, there will be a suite of options for replacing the diversions. The engineering firm will need experience with fish passage, bank stabilization, habitat, floodplain issues, hydrologic experience and riparian enhancement.  OWEB funds are requested for wages/salaries (13%), contracted services (84%), travel (1%) and administration (<1%).  Jubitz Family Foundation, Collins foundation, PBWC and council volunteers will provide cash and in-kind cost-share.

Malheur County SWCD formed a steering committee in February 2014 with the purpose of developing a Candidate Conservation Agreement with Assurances (CCAA) for the greater sage-grouse on private range land in Malheur County. Malheur SWCD, in coordination with USFWS and other partners, started work on several site-specific plans (SSPâ€™s). Staff are needed to prepare the SSP's. OWEB funds are requested for salaries (88%), travel (1%) materials (6%), and administration (5%). Malheur County Sage-grouse Steering Committee, NRCS and OSU Extension are cost-share partners.

The Parsnip Peak Invasive Annuals project area encompasses 10,860 acres of State land (5,332 acres) and private (5,528 acres) in the sagebrush-steppe rangeland eight miles south of Jordan Valley.  Efforts to improve rangeland health complements on-going juniper control effort.  NRCS awarded a $250,000 grant for the Parsnip Peak Invasive Annual Conservation Implementation Strategy (CIS).   Rangeland inventory will occur on 10,860 acres of private and State-owned land and include a combination of on-the-ground and remote sensing. OWEB funds are requested for wages (11%), contracted services (54%), travel (2%), materials (19%), administration (9%) and monitoring (5%). Cost-share partners include landowners, USFWS and NRCS and cost-share is 416% of the OWEB-request.

The Bench Ground project is located seven miles east of Vale on 38 acres of farm ground.  Crops are currently flood-irrigated. Project components include installing:  200 feet of 8-inch pipe; a 5-foot bubbler; 1,010 feet of 6-inch pipe installed from the bubbler to the pivot point; 1,515 feet of cable-in conduit from the 3-phase power to the pivot point; 1,025 feet of cable-in conduit from pivot point to pump located at the bubbler; 20-hp permanent pump and 200 feet of 8-inch pipe from the water source to the bubbler.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (5%), contracted services (16%), materials (68%), travel (4%) and administration (7%).  The landowner will provide cash and in-kind cost-share of 253% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Project Name: Continuing the War on Weeds in the Owyhee
Project Summary: The Jordan Valley Coordinated Weed Management Area (JVCWMA) has been working in the upper Owyhee watershed for over eight years. Project components include education/outreach with the Winter Weed Seminar; Owyhee Field Day; landowner consultations, CWMA board meetings, Annual Weed Work Day and other partner events. OWEB funds are requested for wages (63%), contracted services (6%), travel/mileage (6%), materials (7%), equipment (4%) and administration (13%) and monitoring (1%). Cost-share partners include basin landowners, Oregon State Weed Board, ODFW, BLM, DSL, Malheur County, ODOT and Jordan Valley Irrigation District.  Cost-share for the OWEB-requested amount is 218%.

Project Name: Wallowa Resources' Watershed Evaluation Teams (WET) Program
Project Summary: Wallowa Resources (WR), based in Enterprise, initiated a watershed evaluation team (WET) program designed to provide hands-on experience in data collection that builds environmental awareness for students several years ago. The WET Program reaches  approximately 150 students and 8 teachers in Wallowa County. This program targets 6th, 10th and 11th grade school students in Wallowa County. OWEB funds are requested for wages (83%), supplies (2%), travel (1%) and administration (13%). USFWS, the Nez Perce Tribes (NPT), ODFW, Wallowa SWCD, Wallowa County schools and landowners are cost-share partners.  Positive letters of support were provided by USFWS and NPT.

This project is located 24 miles west of Vale in the Willow Creek drainage and will convert 57 acres from furrow-flood irrigation to sprinkler. Project components include installing 3,260 feet of 8-inch pipe for mainline; install a 1,168 Zimmatic pivot to irrigate 57 acres; 3,260 feet of cable con; a 20-HP pump for the pivot; an 8-inch flowmeter to the pivot and a 10-inch flowmeter from the canal to the pond.  In addition, a willow test plot will be planted along 240 feet of Willow Creek. OWEB funds are requested for wages (10%), contracted services (17%), materials (64%) and administration (8%). The landowner and NRCS will cost-share 186% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Project Name: Mike Williams Chesnimnus Fencing and Off-Site Water Development
Project Summary: Chesnimnus Creek, a tributary to Joseph Creek (RM 49.8), is a major wild summer steelhead  stream in the Grande Ronde basin northeast of Enterprise.  Project components include constructing one mile of 4-strand, barbed-wire, non-continuous fence along section of Chesnimnus Creek; installing two solar livestock watering systems; pump, 48-inch, 10-foot ling culvert and trough.  OWEB funds are requested for  contracted services (36%), materials- pipe, pumps (50%) and administration (13%). ODFW is the cost-share partner and the landowner will provide long-term fence maintenance.

The Alkali Forage Reserve Restoration project is located 30 miles south of Burns on the BLMâ€™s Alkali allotment. The allotment is part of a pipeline network that includes 13 allotments, watering more than 60,000 acres with 100 miles of pipe. The proposed solution is to improve water and forage availability by:  installing 31,680 feet of pipeline; two tire troughs; install a 10,000-gallon storage tank and inter-seed 3,000 acres. OWEB funds are requested for wages (2%), contracted services (21%), materials- pipe, seed (72%) and administration (5%). BLM is the cost-share partner at 35% of the OWEB-requested amount.

Ducks Unlimited and partners from the Harney Basin Wetlands Initiative (HBWI) are seeking a position to conduct landowner outreach and provide technical support to the SONEC (Southern Oregon-Northeast California) area. This is a collaborative partnership with NRCS, Ducks Unlimited, Intermountain Joint Venture, USFWSâ€™ Malheur National Wildlife Refuge and HBWI to further conservation delivery in the Harney basin, a priority subbasin of the SONEC waterfowl priority areas.  There is a lack of capacity for landowner outreach for various programs include the Farm Bill programs obligated to enhance flood-irrigation structure: Oregon NRCS Working Lands for Waterbirds Conservation Implementation Strategy and Conservation Effects Assessment Project. Cost-share (cash) will be provided from NRCS, DU, Intermountain Joint Venture and USFWS- Malheur National Wildlife Refuge to fund this position.  OWEB funds are requested for wages (87%) and administration (13%).

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Summary: This project will, by using aerial maps and GIS analysis, locate and survey significant aspen communities in the Upper South Fork John Day River basin. Once sites are located via GIS, data will be collected on stand vigor, number and type of conifers, structures present, photo documentation and potential restoration identified by cruising each location. OSU specialists will provide training in understanding requirements for healthy aspen communities both through consultation and a public workshop. Partners on this project include private landowners, the Upper South Fork of the John Day River Watershed Council, the Bureau of Land Management, ODFW, NRCS, Grant SWCD, the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, and the USFS.

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Summary: This project is located on Sheep Creek, an intermittent tributary of the South Fork John Day River near Izee in south Grant County.  Due to fire suppression, juniper has encroached into riparian areas, aspen groves and is depleting springs and streams of their normal function and flow.  Historic grazing and wild ungulates have kept aspen from regenerating to a multi-age class canopy. The project will stimulate aspen clone production and protect 12 acres with buck and pole fencing, remove 190 acres of encroaching juniper on the hill slopes around the meadow and in the aspen groves, develop two upland springs for livestock water and treat 90 acres of noxious weeds. Partners on the project include the ranch owner, the Upper South Fork John Day Watershed Council, the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, and Grant SWCD.

This proposal seeks funding for an assessment of hydrologic and geomorphic processes and identification of alternative solutions for the Greasewood watershed near Helix in Umatilla County. Greasewood Creek originates at the top of a 5,200 acre basin of intensively managed agricultural lands, flowing past Helix and into Wildhorse Creek, a tributary of the Umatilla River. Historic farming practices have altered the natural processes of Greasewood Creek, creating issues with high sediment loads, channelization, degraded floodplains and flooding. Land management practices have significantly improved in recent years, shifting toward conservation tillage, crop rotations and enrollment in CREP but the sediment routing issues continue. The assessment will include alternatives to restore natural channel and floodplain form and morphology, restore floodplain connectivity and improve flood attenuation through a range of high flow events, restore historic hydrologic regime and a more naturalized hydrograph, decrease channel erosion, and improve sediment and flow routing. Numerous partners support this project, including a long list of landowners in the basin, Natural Resource Conservation Service, Oregon Department of Agriculture, Oregon Department of Transportation, the City of Helix, Helix Parks and Recreation, Umatilla County and the Umatilla County SWCD.

This project site is on 13,400 acres in northern Grant County including 10 miles of Desolation Creek before it flows into the North Fork of the John Day River. The project will address degraded wet meadow and spring habitat in order to re-establish flow and improve habitat. On the property, abundant springs and their associated wet-meadow habitats have been unprotected and degraded by decades of intensive grazing and logging. Where flow once contributed to Desolation Creek, several springs are trampled to the extent that water is pooling in hoof-prints rather than running toward the waterway. Springs and outflow channels have been stripped of protective vegetation causing channel incision and riparian degradation. Associated aspen stands are in decline and over-dense forests are encroaching on these wet-meadow ecosystems. This proposal includes installing 8,448 feet of fencing around wet meadows, developing five springs with off-site water for livestock, thinning six acres of encroaching forest thickets and protecting two stands of aspen. Partners on this project include Desolation Creek LLC, Umatilla National Forest, North Fork John Day Watershed Council, Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, and the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife.

This project is located in northern Sherman County, one of the major wheat producing areas in the state. Cropland can be vulnerable to sheet and rill erosion during extreme weather events such as rain on snow or flashy rain storms. This erosion causes excessive sediment transport into natural draws and swales resulting in degraded water quality as it reaches perennial streams. To resolve this issue, this project would install terraces and water and sediment control basins (WASCBs) on cropland slopes to catch and slow down overland flows, dropping out sediment before it reaches live water. Project components include building 11,970 feet of terrace and 15 cropland WASCBS. Partners on this project include Sherman Co Area Watershed Council, Sherman SWCD, NRCS and the landowner.

This proposal seeks funding to hire leaders and instructors for a county-wide program integrating high school age students in restoration activities and on-the-ground learning. Maintaining a healthy ecosystem requires both current and a long-term commitment. By involving youth in restoration now, they not only take those lessons back home but also into their future. Partners in this program include the Oregon Youth Conservation Corp (OYCC), Oregon Community Foundation, the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and the USFS.

Project Name: STELLAR Watershed Education and Community Outreach
Project Summary: This program, focusing in the Milton Freewater area in Umatilla County, will increase both student and adult understanding of why healthy streams and adjoining riparian and upland zones are critical to salmon and steelhead habitat. Over 500 students and 100 adults will be involved in multiple program activities that aim to educate on the status of Salmon and steelhead, and local issues that contribute to the need for restoration. Activities include hands-on restoration involvement by both students and adults. Partners on this program include the Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council, the Milton-Freewater Unified School District, the Wildhorse Foundation, the Blue Mountain Foundation, Diack Ecology, and many volunteers.

Project Name: Meredith Diversion Nos. 1 and 2 Replacement Project
Project Summary: This project, located on Beech Creek in Grant County, seeks funding to consolidate two irrigation diversions into a single, fish-friendly structure. Beech Creek is an important steelhead spawning and juvenile Chinook rearing tributary of the John Day River. The two existing structures currently impede fish passage for some life stages of salmonids during critical times of the year. Partners on this project include the landowner, Bureau of Reclamation and the Grant SWCD.

This project is located within the Bear Creek sub-watershed of the Silvies River basin in southeast Grant County. Aspen stands and a wet meadow site within the project area have been degraded due to conifer encroachment, as well as domestic and wild ungulate grazing. This proposal seeks funding to treat four aspen communities totaling 5 acres to promote tree regeneration, construct livestock exclusion and management fencing on both aspen (5 acres) and wet meadows (32 acres) and establish six spring development water sources to serve new pasture units. Partners on this project include Grant SWCD and the landowner.

The project sites are located in the northern drainages of the Middle Fork John Day River, near Galena in Grant County. Big Creek, East Fork Big Creek, Pizer Creek, Lost Creek and Deadwood Creek and a series of six wet meadows within these drainages present a mixture of limiting factors. These creeks provide core spawning and rearing habitat for Bull Trout, Steelhead and Chinook salmon. However, the habitat which supports these species has been detrimentally altered due to historic logging, grazing, mining, beaver trapping, road construction and homesteads. The six meadows identified as project sites currently have gullies that drain erosive overland flow, rather than allowing it to soak into the ground. The proposed streams are over-stocked with encroaching conifers and have issues with floodplain connectivity and channel simplification evident by reduced large wood recruitment and low diversity in riparian vegetation. The proposed treatment will drop or tip select trees into the riparian zone, opening up the canopy for riparian hardwoods to re-establish and the large wood adding roughness to both channel and floodplain; and thin portions of conifer encroachment into meadows and place coarse, woody debris in eroding gullies to catch sediment and hold-back overland flows. Partners on this project include the North Fork John Day Watershed Council and the Malheur National Forest.

This project is located on Cottonwood Creek in northwest Grant County near the town of Monument. After the completion of an extensive assessment and prioritization of fish passage barriers on the lower twelve miles of Cottonwood Creek, Monument SWCD and partners have begun to correct those at the top of the list. Four sites were identified as top priorities â€“ three have been completed or are in the process of being corrected - this proposal would correct the fourth and final of the highest priority sites. This project would consolidate two irrigation push-up dams that pose a barrier for juvenile steelhead and Chinook attempting to seek refuge in the upper Cottonwood Creek basin from the warmer waters of the North Fork John Day River. One of these diversions currently supplies water to an unscreened open irrigation ditch that has the high potential to strand fish in the field. Additionally, the other diversion conveyance is over 1,000â€™ of leaky above-ground mainline which loses a significant amount of water during transport to the field.   The project proposes to combine the two points of diversions into one fish-friendly rock weir-style diversion structure so the two push-up dams can be abandoned. ODFW will install a fish screen at the new diversion site that will exclude fish from both irrigation systems. The leaking, above-ground mainline will be replaced with 1,200â€™ of buried PVC pipe. Partners on the project include the Monument SWCD, ODFW, Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs, USFWS Partners Program and the landowner.

This proposal seeks funding for a multi-pronged approach to reach 175 students, 40 landowners/managers and 1,000 members of the general public. The program is based out of Wheeler County and will use workshops, hands-on activities linked to restoration projects, an interactive streamtable and a kiosk to increase knowledge and understanding of the value of healthy, functioning natural systems in the watershed. Partners on this proposal include the Mid John Day Bridge Creek Watershed Council, the Wheeler SWCD, OSU Extension and Wheeler County schools.

This project is located along Butte Creek, a tributary of the John Day River in northwest Wheeler County. Four fish passage barriers, located above the town of Fossil, restrict upstream connectivity to good steelhead habitat. Currently three undersized, failing and/or perched culverts and one headcut are barriers to fish movement. This section of Butte Creek has undergone quite a bit of restoration - all four sites are either enrolled in CREP or are fenced to exclude the riparian areas from grazing. The three culverts will be replaced with bottomless pipe arch culverts that meet ODFW fish passage requirements for steelhead. The passage at the headcut will be corrected by installing a stream simulation riffle to create a stable transition between the two elevations and provide fish passage at all flows. Partners on this project include the Wheeler SWCD and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

This project is located on Badger Creek, an upper steelhead tributary of the John Day River in southeast Wheeler County. This is the third highest diversion in the Mountain Creek watershed and it was identified as a fish passage barrier in the Mountain Creek Reach Evaluation/Action Plan.  The open ditch downstream of the diversion is in close proximity to the stream and can breach causing negative water quality. The diversion will be replaced with a stream simulated diversion that will provide passage for all life stages of fish at all flows. The area immediately around the diversion will be fenced. 1,500 feet of the open ditch near the stream will be replaced with buried pipe. There is already a functioning fish screen on location but a flow measuring device will be built on the downstream end to facilitate better water management. Partners on the project include Wheeler SWCD and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

This project is located on Indian Creek, a high elevation tributary of Badger Creek and Mountain Creek, in southeast Wheeler County. Mountain Creek becomes Rock Creek before it enters the John Day River. This property has three diversions on Indian Creek that are used for irrigation. None of the existing diversions allow for fish passage, are screened or have flow measuring devices installed. Currently, passage can be totally blocked depending on the flow and irrigation demands. In the past, ditch failure and overtopping have degraded water quality instream. The project will replace the upper and middle diversions with fish-friendly structures, install fish screens and flow measuring devices, convert 4,100 feet of ditch to pipe and totally abandon the lowest diversion. The water right allows water to be diverted from any of the three points of diversion, so no water right transfers are needed. Partners on this project include the Wheeler SWCD, NRCS and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

Project Name: Headwaters of Bridge Creek Watershed Improvement
Project Summary: This project is located in southeast Wheeler County, in the Bridge Creek watershed which drains into the John Day River. The combination of invasive species encroachment in the riparian area, loss of native vegetation, juniper/ponderosa pine encroachment into historic grasslands, past land use practices, and fire suppression has created a decline in quality upland habitat and reduced water quantity and quality in the headwaters of the Bridge Creek basin. This project seeks funds to remove 400 acres of juniper, pre-commercial thin 55 acres of Ponderosa pine, and reseed 180 acres mechanically disturbed during juniper removal process.  This is just one part of a landscape scale treatment that will result in over 3,585 acres of juniper removed, 375 acres of forest stand improvements, 10 miles of Bridge Creek and 268 acres of riparian zone enrolled in FSAâ€™s Conservation Reserve Enhancement Program (CREP) and a follow-up prescribed burn schedule to keep juniper from re-establishing. Partners on this project include two landowners, Wheeler SWCD, NRCS and the Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs.

Grantee: Upper South Fork John Day WC
Project Name: John Day River Sub-Yearling Spring Chinook Salmon Monitoring to Enhance Population Productivity
Project Summary: Juvenile Spring Chinook salmon in the Upper Mainstem John Day River encounter density dependent limitations on rearing space. Density dependence restricts production of yearling fish migrants, hence limits adult abundance. Little is known about the abundance, distribution and physiology of downstream rearing juvenile Chinook in the John Day River basin. Monitoring this life history will help focus on restoration projects that benefit juvenile rearing habitat. The monitoring sites are located in both the lower South Fork John Day River and mainstem John Day River in Grant County. Partners include the Upper South Fork of the John Day Watershed Council, Oregon State University and ODFW.
